msContents.textLang: Middle English, using forms attested in Kent and Essex; with Latin

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Canterbury Tales
msItem.incipit:
There as this lord was keper of the selle
The rule of seint Maure or of seint Beneit
msItem.explicit:
Beth fructuous and that in litil space
And to do wel god send you his grace
msItem.note: Begins at I.172. Verse ends fol. 232r.

msItem.title: The General Prologue
msItem.incipit:
There as this lord was keper of the selle
The rule of seint Maure or of seint Beneit
msItem.explicit:
And he bigan with riȝt a mery chiere
His tale anon & seide as ye may here

msItem.title: The Knight’s Tale
msItem.rubric: Iamque domos patrias scithice post aspera gentis prelia lauri gero & cetera.
Hic incipit fabula militis.
msItem.incipit:
WHilom as olde stories tellen us
Ther was a duc that hiȝt Theseus
msItem.explicit:
Thus endeth Palamoun and Emelie
And god saue all this faire company Amen
msItem.note: I.1374–59, 2655 omitted; Hic deficit in margin next to 1360.

msItem.title: The Knight-Miller link
msItem.rubric: Here beginneth the prolog of the Millere
msItem.incipit:
Whan that the knight had thus his tale Itolde
In al the company nas ther yong ne olde
msItem.explicit:
Auiseth you and put me out of blame
And eke men shal not make ernest of game
msItem.finalRubric: Here is ended the Prolog of the Meller

msItem.title: The Miller’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth his tale folwing
msItem.incipit:
Whilom ther was dwelling at Oxenford
A riche gnoff that gestes helde to borde
msItem.explicit:
And Nicholas is scalded in his toute
This tale is don and god saue all the route
msItem.finalRubric: Here is ended the Millers tale

msItem.title: The Reeve’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth the Prolog of the Reue
msItem.incipit:
Whan folk had laughen at this nise caas
Of Absolon and hende Nicholas
msItem.explicit:
He can wel in myn ye seen a stalk
But in his owne ye he cannot seen a balk
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the Prolog of the Reue

msItem.title: The Reeve’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth his tale folwing
msItem.incipit:
At trompington nat fer fro cambrigge
Ther goth a brook and ouer that a brigge
msItem.explicit:
A gilour shal him self be giled be
And god that sitteth hy in mageste…

msItem.title: The Cook’s Tale
msItem.incipit:
And ther they setten steuene for to mete
And playen at the dys in such a strete
msItem.explicit:
And had a wif that helde for contenaunce
A shoppe and swyued for her sustenaunce
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the Cookes tale

msItem.title: The Introduction to the Man of Law’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth the lawiers prolog with his tale folwing
msItem.incipit:
Oure oost sauȝ wel þat the brigt sonne
The Ark of his artificiall day hath ronne
msItem.explicit:
And with that word he with a sobir chiere
Began his tale as ye shall aftir here
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the Prolog of the Man of Lawe

msItem.title: The Man of Law’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth his tale folwing
msItem.incipit:
O hateful harme condicion of pouierte
With thirst with colde with hunger so confounded
msItem.explicit:
Nor that a Marchaunt goon is many a yere
Me tauȝt a tale as ye shall aftir here

msItem.title: The Man of Law’s Tale
msItem.incipit:
In surrye somwhile dwelt a company
Of chapmen riche and therto sad and true
msItem.explicit:
Ioye aftir woo gouerne vs in his grace
And kepe us alle that beth in this place
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the tale of the man of lawe

msItem.title: The ‘Epilogue’ of the Man of Law’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth the Prolog of the Squier
msItem.incipit:
Oure oost upon his stiropes stood anon
And seide gode men herkeneth euerichon
msItem.explicit:
Ne Phisilias ne termes of queynt lawe
Ther is but litill latyn in my mawe
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the prolog of the Squier
msItem.note: Functions as a link to the Squire’s Tale but has sompnour at 1179.

msItem.title: The Squire’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth his tale folwing
msItem.incipit:
At sarray in the land of tartary
Ther dwelt a kyng that werried Russy
msItem.explicit:
ffor Canacee or that he miȝt hir wynne
And there I left I wil agein bigynne
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit prima pars
msItem.note: V.671–2 omitted. Following verso ruled but blank.

msItem.title: The ‘Squire-Franklin Link’
msItem.rubric: Here beginneth the Prolog of the Marchaunt
msItem.incipit:
In feith squire thou hast the wel quit
And gently I preise wel thi wit
msItem.explicit:
I pray to god that I may plese you
Than wot I wel that it is gode Inow
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the Prolog of the Marchaunt
msItem.note: The link here functions to conjoin the Squire’s and Merchant’s Tales, with ‘Merchant’ appearing instead of ‘Franklin’ in V.675, 696, and 699.

msItem.title: The Merchant’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And he beginneth his tale folwing as ye shal here
msItem.incipit:
Whilom ther was dwelling in Lombardye
A lusty kniȝt that was born at Pauye
msItem.explicit:
Thus endid is my tale of Ianuarie
God blisse vs and his moder seint Marie Amen
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the Marchauntes tale

msItem.title: The Clerk’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth the Prolog of the Clerk of Oxenford
msItem.incipit:
Sir clerk of oxenford our oost said
Ye ride as stille and coy as doth a mayde
msItem.explicit:
Saue that he wole conueyen his matere
But this is his tale which ye may here
msItem.finalRubric: Hic finitur Prologus Clerici Oxonie

msItem.title: The Clerk’s Tale
msItem.rubric: Et hic Incipit bona fabula nuncupata Grisilde de qua dam muliere que Raro Videtur et cetera
msItem.incipit:
Ther is right at the west side of ytayle
Doun at the roote of vesulus the colde
msItem.explicit:
Be ay of chere as liȝt as lief on lynde
And lete him care wepe wrynge and wayle
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the tale of the Clerk of Oxenford and his good song

msItem.title: The Wife of Bath’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth the Prolog of the wif of Bathe
msItem.incipit:
Experience thouȝ non auctorite
Were in this world is right I now for me
msItem.explicit:
If I haue licence of this worthi frere
Yes dame telle forth quod he and I will here
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the Prolog of the wif of Bathe
msItem.note: III.696–766 lost; 575–84, 609–12, 619–26, omitted; spurious lines follow 543, 544.

msItem.title: The Wife of Bath’s Tale
msItem.rubric: With here tale folwing
msItem.incipit:
In the olde dayes of kyng arthour
Of which that bretons speken gret honour
msItem.explicit:
And olde and angry nygardes of dispence
God send hem sone verry pestilence
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the tale of the Wif of Bathe

msItem.title: The Friar’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth the Prolog of the ffrere
msItem.incipit:
This worthy limitour this noble frere
He made alwey a maner louryng chere
msItem.explicit:
And aftir this he said vnto the frere
Telle forth your tale leue maystir dere
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the Prolog of the ffrere

msItem.title: The Friar’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth his tale folwing
msItem.incipit:
Whilom there was dwellyng in my contre
An Archedeken a man of hiȝe degre
msItem.explicit:
And praieth that this sompnour him repente
Of his mysdedes or that the fend han hent
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the tale of the ffrere

msItem.title: The Sommoner’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth the Prolog of the sompnour
msItem.incipit:
This sompnour in his stiroppes high he stood
Vpon this frere his herte was wood
msItem.explicit:
God saue you alle saue this cursed frere
My prolog wol I ende in this manere
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the Prolog of the Sompnour

msItem.title: The Summoner’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth his tale folwing
msItem.incipit:
Lordinges ther is in Yorkeshire as I gesse
A merssh contre I callid holdernesse
msItem.explicit:
And Iankyn hath I wonne a newe gowne
My tale is don we ben almost at towne
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the sompnors tale

msItem.title: The Prologue of the Second Nun’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth the seconde Nonnes tale
msItem.incipit:
The ministre and norice vnto vices
Which that men clepen in englissh ydilnesse
msItem.explicit:
And brenne euer in charite full briȝt
Now haue I declared what she hiȝt

msItem.title: The Second Nun’s Tale
msItem.rubric: Fabula Sancta Cecilia
msItem.incipit:
This maiden briȝt Cecely as her lif seith
Was come of romayns and of noble kynde
msItem.explicit:
In which into this day in noble wise
Men do to crist and to his seint seruice
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the seconde Nonnes tale

msItem.title: The Pardoner’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth the Prolog of the Pardoner
msItem.incipit:
Lordinges quod he in chirche whan I preche
I peyne me to han an haute speche
msItem.explicit:
Which I am wont to preche for to wynne
Now holde your pees my tale I will begynne
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the Prolog of the Pardoner

msItem.title: The Pardoner’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth his tale folwing
msItem.incipit:
In flaundres whilom was a companye
Of yong folk that haunted foly
msItem.explicit:
And as we did let us lauȝe and pley
Anon they kissed and riden forth her wey
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the Pardoners tale

msItem.title: The Manciple’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth the Manciples Prolog
msItem.incipit:
Wote ye not where ther stont a litel toun
Which that clepid is Bobbe vp and doun
msItem.explicit:
Telle on Manciple I they prey
Wel sir quod he now herkeneth what I sey
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the Prolog of the Manciple

msItem.title: The Manciple’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth his tale folwing
msItem.incipit:
Whan phebus dwellid in this world adoun
As olde bokes make mencioun
msItem.explicit:
Where so thou come among hiȝe or lowe
Kepe well thi tonge and thenke vpon the crowe
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the Manciples tale

msItem.title: The Sir Thopas
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth A tale of Maister Chaucer
msItem.incipit:
Listenith lordinges in good entent
And I will telle you verralment
msItem.explicit:
As did the kniȝt Sir Percyuelle
So worthi vnder wode

msItem.title: The ‘Thopas-Melibee Link’
msItem.incipit:
Nomore of this for goddis dignite
Quod oure oost for thou makest me
msItem.explicit:
And herkeneth what that I shall say
And late me telle my tale I pray
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the tale of Maister Chaucer

msItem.title: The Tale of Melibee
msItem.rubric: And here ye shuyl fynde a moral tale of Melibe and Prudence
msItem.note: Omits 2996 and parts of 2182, 2263–4, 2266–7, 2432, 3058–9; lacks 2484–959, i.e. 475 prose sentences of irregular length, through loss of leaves after fol. 191; ends 11 lines down fol. 194r, leaving remainder of page blank.

msItem.rubric: Here beginneth the Nonnes Prestes tale of Chauntecler & Pertelote

msItem.title: The Nun’s Priest’s Tale
msItem.incipit:
A pore widewe somdel stope in ag
Was whilom dwelling in a narwe cotage
msItem.explicit:
As seith my lord so make us alle gode men
And bringe us to his hiȝe blisse Amen
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the Nonnes Prestes tale

msItem.title: The Physician’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth A tale of the Maister of Phisik
msItem.incipit:
There was as telleth us Titus liueus
A kniȝt that Cleped was Virgeneus
msItem.explicit:
Therfor I rede ye this counseill take
fforsake synne or synne you forsake
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the tale of the Maister of Phisik

msItem.title: The Shipman’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth the Shipmannes tale of a Marchaunt
msItem.incipit:
A marchaunt whilom duelled at seint Denys
That riche was for which men helde him wyse
msItem.explicit:
Thus endeth now my tale and god us sende
Talkyng I nouȝ vnto oure lyues ende
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the shipmannes tale

msItem.title: The ‘Shipman-Prioress Link’
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth the Prolog of the Prioresse
msItem.incipit:
Wel said be corpus dominus quod oure oost
Now longe mot thou saile be the coste
msItem.explicit:
Now wol ye vouchesaf my lady dere
Gladly quod she and seid in this manere

msItem.title: The Prioress’s Prologue
msItem.incipit:
O lord oure lord thi name hou merueilous
Is in this large world sprad quod she
msItem.explicit:
Riȝt so faire I and therfor I you pray
Endeth my song that I shall of you say
msItem.finalRubric: Here is ended the Prolog of the Prioresse

msItem.title: The Prioress’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth her tale folwing
msItem.incipit:
Ther was in Asie in a gret citee
Among cristen folk of Iury
msItem.explicit:
On vs his gret mercy multiplie
ffor reuerence of his moder Marie
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the Prioresse tale

msItem.title: The Franklin’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth the Prolog of the Marchaunt
msItem.incipit:
This olde gentil bretons in her daies
Of dyuers aduentures maden layes
msItem.explicit:
My spirit feleth nouȝt of such matere
But if ye list my tale ye may here
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the Prolog of the Marchaunt
msItem.note: Although structured as a ‘Merchant’s Prologue’, the link is followed by Franklin’s Tale.

msItem.title: The Franklin’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth his tale folwing
msItem.incipit:
In armorik that called was britayne
Ther was a kniȝt that loued and did his payne
msItem.explicit:
Now telleth me or that ye further wende
I can no more my tale is at an ende
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the tale of the Marchaunt
msItem.note: Although referred to as the ‘Merchant’s Tale’ in the incipit and explicit, the text is that of the Franklin’s Tale. V.1455–6, 1493–8 omitted; 731–2, 893–4 reversed; 999–1000 follow 1006; 1541–4 follow 1550.

msItem.title: The Parson’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And here beginneth the Prolog of the Person
msItem.incipit:
Than the marchaunt had his tale endid
The sonne fro the south side is discendid
msItem.explicit:
Beth fructuous and that in litil space
And to do wel god send you his grace

supportDesc.collation: 112 (fols. 1–5; wants 1–7), 2–512 (fols. 6–53, signed q, r, t, σ [?]), 612–1 (fols. 54–64, signed x, wants 8th after fol. 60), 712 (fols. 65–76, signed y), 812+one (fols. 77–89, signed z; fol. 89, a singleton, signed A[?]), 912 (fols. 90–101, signed b), 108–1 (fols. 102–108, with the stub glued to fol. 108v; wants 8th after fol. 108), 1112–1 (fols. 109–119, signed +, wants 12th after fol. 119), 1212 (fols. 120–131, signed a), 1312–1 (fols. 132–142; wants 4th after fol. 134), 14–1712 (fols. 143–190, signed [?], d, c), 1812–10 (fols. 191–192, signed g; wants 2nd–11th after fol. 191), 19–2412 (fols. 193–264, signed h, i, k, l, m, n), 258–1 (fols. 265–270; wants 6th after fol. 268). Catchwords. Signatures from fol. 6r with q 1, ending with z 6 on fol. 82r; fol. 89 is a singleton. A new series begins on fol. 121 with a 1. It is thus possible that 14 or 15 quires once preceded fol. 1.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in violet ink in 34 long lines, ruled space 260 140

handDesc.handNote: Gothic hybrida, designated the work of a Hooked-g scribe or scribes; see Daniel W. Mosser and Linne R. Mooney, The Case of the Hooked-g Scribe(s) and the Production of Middle English Literature, c. 1460–c. 1490; Holly James-Maddocks, The Illuminators of the Hooked-g Scribe(s) and the Production of Middle English Literature, c. 1460–c. 1490 (who refers to the copyist as Hooked-g Scribe 2).

decoDesc.summary: Pächt and Alexander iii. 1062, pl. XCVIII: fine borders, historiated and other initials. In two styles. Pen flourishes, and initials.
decoDesc.decoNote: Initials and borders, decorated with sprays of foliage, flowers and gold disks, at the beginning of Tales and Prologues on fols. 44r, 55r, 63r, 79v, 90v, 149r, 165v, 175r, 204r, 115v, 219r, 233v.

item.seg: Friar with raised hand, standing in pulpit (Prologue to the Friar's Tale).
Melibee(?) or Geoffrey Chaucer(??) in fine dress, seated at lectern with an open book (The Tale of Melibee).

decoDesc.decoNote: Rubricated with enlarged display script and added flourishes. Running heads, with instructions for copying found occasionally at the right foot of pages, such as fol. 255r (dorigen) and 255v (arveragus).

binding.p: Formerly in an 18th-century binding, tanned calf over laminated pulpboard.
Rebound in brown buckram with calf spine, sewn on six thongs, 1985.

origin.p: Scott, Later Gothic Manuscripts 1390–1490 (London, 1996), 2:141, argues for the date. On a linguistic basis, the scribe was presumably from the Thames Estuary.

history.provenance: On fol. 169v, below the writing space, in drypoint, is wyke.

Sixteenth-century inscriptions, John Opowell (fol. 270v), T. Hull (fol. 240r), Ann Taylor (fols. 43r and 249r), John Crowland (fol. 270r). The word pope has been erased at II. 234 and elsewhere. John M. Manly and Edith Rickert, eds., The Text of the Canterbury Tales Studied on the Basis of All Known Manuscripts (Chicago, 1940), 1:468–71 suggest possible identifications.
Sir Norton Knatchbull (1602-1685): at his sale, Bullord S.C. 22 June 1698, lot 39; bought by:
Thomas Sclater Bacon (d. 1737‏): at his sale, Bullord S.C. 14 March 1736/7, lot 2075; bought by:
history.acquisition: Likely bequeathed to the Bodleian c. 1748, separately from his 1755 bequest. Former shelfmark, Arch. C. Bodl. 83

recordHist.source: Description by Andrew Dunning (July 2022), with contents revised from the Digital Index of Middle English Verse and reference to earlier published descriptions. Decoration, localization and date previously described in Pächt and Alexander (1973), with additional description of decoration by Elizabeth Solopova (2000); also described in the Summary Catalogue: Summary Catalogue, Vol. 3, p. 332 Summary Catalogue, Vol. 3, p. 333

ref.title: A Digital Catalogue of the Pre-1500 Manuscripts and Incunables of the Canterbury Tales
Digital Index of Middle English Verse

msContents.summary: Lydgate fragment from Cologny, Fondation Martin Bodmer, Cod. Bodmer 110, once forming endleaves to MS. Rawl. poet. 223 and now housed separately following rebinding in 1985. Another part of the manuscripts survive in Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Rawl. D. 913, fols. 2r–3v.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Troy Book
msItem.incipit:
To rede Bookes of thantiquitie
To fyn oonly vertue forto sue
msItem.explicit:
þus deme I fully in myn oppynioun
ffor of þyn age thy wytt þi providence
msItem.note: Fragment: Prologue, lines 80–384 (end) and Book I, lines 1–459.

supportDesc.foliation: Leaves foliated separately from the host volume: the detached leaves have the same style of foliation as that in the Bodmer 110 manuscript.

decoDesc.summary: Pächt and Alexander iii. 1083, pl. C:

origin.origPlace: London, according to Kathleen Scott, A Mid-Fifteenth-Century English Illuminating Shop and Its Customers

revisionDesc.change: Andrew Dunning Revised with consultation of original.

Toby Burrows/Mapping Manuscript MigrationsProvenance and acquisition information added using https://github.com/mapping-manuscript-migrations/oxford-tei-updates/blob/master/update_oxford_prov.rb in collaboration with the Mapping Manuscript Migrations project.
James Cummings Up-converted the markup using https://github.com/jamescummings/Bodleian-msDesc-ODD/blob/master/convertTolkien2Bodley.xsl
